docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''As the Tiniest Babies Grow, So Can Their Problems'' (front page, May 8): Studies are not only ''intensifying the long-running debate about the ethics of using sophisticated technology to save children with uncertain futures,'' but are also intensifying other ethical scenarios.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was just an ordinary day in the life of Britain's most prominent working couple when Cherie Blair dropped in unannounced on her husband, Tony, the British prime minister, as he went about the nation's business in his Downing Street office. Nothing surprising about that. The official residence sports a laid-back appearance these days, with aides in shirt sleeves and loosened ties keeping up a lively banter in the corridors of British power and the wife of the prime minister frequently breezing past the busts of William Pitt and Benjamin Disraeli on her way down from the family quarters upstairs, out the famous black front door with the white numeral 10 and off to her job as one of London's top downtown lawyers.
docs.abstract: Warren Hoge article on political and personal life of Britain's Prime Tony Blair; says Blair and his wife, Cherie, are expecting their fourth child and their first in 12 years, and newcomer is presenting Blair with test right in his own home of his frequently voiced notions of new, improved, up-to-date, socially advanced, even cool Britain; says Blair is faced with widespread public anticipation that he will take some of paternity leave that his reform-minded government has made part of British law, and his modern-man reputation is on the line; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It was just an ordinary day in the life of Britain's most prominent working couple when Cherie Blair dropped in unannounced on her husband, Tony, the British prime minister, as he went about the nation's business in his Downing Street office.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As long as there are dedicated neonatologists and hopeful parents, premature babies with very low birthweights will be born (front page, May 8). Most of these babies will grow up with few, if any, long-term health problems. But many will have special health care needs of some kind. Instead of focusing on the implied question of the worth of a baby who survives low birthweight and has disabilities or a chronic health condition, we should turn our attention to two areas: healthy pregnancies and services for babies and children with special needs and their families.
docs.abstract: Polly Arango letter says babies will be born with very low birthweights as long as there are dedicated neonatologists and hopeful parents; says focus ought to be on healthy pregnancies and helping babies and children with special needs (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: MOTHERKIND By Jayne Anne Phillips 295 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24. In fierce, magical works like ''Black Tickets'' (1979) and ''Machine Dreams'' (1984) Jayne Anne Phillips depicted characters torn between the dream of home -- ''a two-lane road densely overhung with the deciduous trees of a more familiar world'' -- and the dream of escape. Restless survivors of the 60's, these people found themselves on the road, on the move, on the lam, and yet their very rootlessness and dislocation left them haunted by the families and vanished small-town worlds they had tried to leave behind. Though Kate, the heroine of Ms. Phillips's disappointing new novel, shares an emotional resume with her earlier creations -- a girlhood in Appalachia, years of aimless wandering, a sense of fragmentation and loss -- she has now settled down to a life of quiet domesticity in the outskirts of Boston. She has become what her husband, Matt, calls ''the Queen of Safety'': she has ''circled the wagons'' around her family, and wants ''everything absolutely tacked down,'' as she struggles to take care of her newborn son and her ailing mother, Katherine.

headline.main: Caretaker for Both Son and Mother

docs.lead_paragraph: SLEEP-DEPRIVED -- that's the disclaimer Stacy Schiff, who's won the Pulitzer for biography, throws over her interview. She spent five years on her book about the marriage of Vera Nabokov, but what's concerning her now is her own domestic life. The new baby is 2 weeks old and nursing, her 7-year-old daughter has a strep throat, the 8-year-old son's birthday party is coming up -- ever put together a child's birthday party? -- Ms. Schiff, a breakneck New York speed talker, is saying. Would you like to come over Saturday and take a shot? She doubts she'll make any sense.

headline.main: A Biographer Peers, Briefly, at Her Own Life

docs.abstract: Public Lives column profiles career of Stacy Schiff, who won Pulitzer Prize for biography for her book Vera, biography of Vera Nabokov; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Forty years ago today, the Food and Drug Administration approved a medication that set off a medical and social revolution. The medication was an oral contraceptive called Enovid, introduced in 1960 by Searle to a nation of women increasingly eager for greater certainty in preventing unwanted pregnancies. Though few realized it then, ''the Pill,'' as it came to be called, has turned out to have a number of ancillary health benefits as well as some serious side effects.

headline.main: The Pill at 40: New Uses for a Drug That Changed Society

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on 40th anniversary of Food and Drug Administration approval of birth control pill; notes women can now choose from 59 different products, all variations on original theme; holds current formulations are remarkably safe; cites side effects and health benefits; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In this land of musical effervescence and, lately, political uproar, a silence spoke louder than either after an account of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony by Sir Simon Rattle and the Vienna Philharmonic this evening. The performance, at which the audience had been asked not to applaud, took place at the quarry of a former Nazi camp here, 120 miles east of Vienna. And although it had been in planning stages for four years, mostly without opposition, it recently became a hot issue. Critics of the idea said it trivialized an infamous slaughterhouse of the Holocaust and demeaned the memory of those who died here. Others labeled the Philharmonic's action merely as ineffectual given the rise of Jorg Haider and his pugnacious right-wing Freedom Party. And the strongest opposition came from survivors of the Mauthausen camp and its dozens of satellites throughout Austria, and those who claimed to speak for them.

headline.main: ARTS ABROAD: Dissonance In the Shadow Of Death; Beethoven and Kaddish Echo Through a Nazi Camp Site

docs.abstract: James R Oestreich column on controversial performance by Sir Simon Rattle and Vienna Philharmonic of Beethoven symphony, Mauthausen, Austria, at site of former Nazi death camp; notes Leon Zelman, camp survivor, proposed concert to call attention to part of history often ignored by Austrians; event, including Jewish mourning prayers, is broadcast on video screens in major cities and on Austrian television; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the 1960's, researchers began diagnosing hereditary disorders by examining the amniotic fluid surrounding the fetuses carried by pregnant women considered at high risk. By the 1970's, amniocentesis had become available to women of advanced maternal age. Now, amniocentesis is routine. In testing, about three tablespoons of amniotic fluid with discarded fetal cells are withdrawn from the uterus, cultured in the lab and inspected for abnormalities.

headline.main: When Fetal Tests Weigh Heavy on Prospective Parents

docs.abstract: Edited transcripts of interviews conducted by Prof Rayna Rapp with pregnant women who have used amniocentesis over last 10 years to test fetus for birth defects; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty years ago, obstetricians listened for the reassuring sound of a fetal heartbeat and felt a woman's abdomen to monitor fetal growth and position. It was, in essence, educated guesswork, trying to visualize the unborn baby without ever really seeing it. In the late 1970's, obstetricians started to see it all. New kinds of ultrasound machines revolutionized prenatal monitoring. For the first time, physicians, mothers and fathers could look at the fetus's beating heart and squiggling hands and feet. Expectant parents left the doctor's office with goodie bags, envelopes filled with early baby photos.

headline.main: Advances, and Angst, in a New Era of Ultrasound

docs.abstract: Ultrasound fetal monitoring is on verge of yet another revolution, with latest gadgets creating three-dimensional images of fetus and monitoring blood flow of fetal organs; another technique being studied may eventually reduce need for amniocentesis and chorionic villus sampling to detect birth defects; widespread use of ultrasound is raising new questions about how much information expectant parents want and whether all those using ultrasound know what new images mean; photo (M)
